Say hello to Reyna, she's the first person you see.
author: Travis S.

description:
Ah shit, the plumber's here. Don't get me wrong. I am really really thrilled to see the plumber. Especially since he left us without a working bathroom sink and minimal water pressure in the kitchen sink. Over two weeks ago. Then dude goes MIA on us. And he has the keys to the house. But he's cute and he's Irish. You learn to forgive a lot when a cute Irish plumber shows back up to fix things.


But that means the water's off. So, no cooking. So, I'm sitting at home, on my day off, writing endless reviews on yelp. Catching up, as it may. And getting hungrier by the minute. And reading reviews. And now my stomach's grumbling.


I think I'll go to Casa Mexicana. Because La Carreta sucks. And the last time I went to El Castillo, the dude was SO CRACKED OUT that I was afraid a drop of his stimulant-laden sweat would fall into my food and I would be tripping. And not hungry because I was tripping so hard. So, I haven't been back to El Castillo in, like, 3 years. Even though we can probably safely assume that cracked out burrito maker 1. died of a heart attack or 2. cleaned up his act.


Casa Mexicana has fresh food. Clean restaurant. Funky Mexican Art-inspired interior. Good salsa. I judge salsa by the green stuff. Anyone can throw some tomatoes and onions and jalapenos together. Green salsa's where it's at. And really nice servers who will put the tortilla on the grill & melt the cheese on it if I ask. Nicely. I always ask nicely because burritos are important and the people who make them for you are also important. Treat them with respect and they will treat your burrito with respect.
author: Yasi S.

description:
I've only been here once. I had the grilled fish taco and a side of rice. They were both okay. 

But they give you free chips ans salsa. AND they have a salsa bar where you can help yourself to cilantro, onions, jalapenos, and a variety of, YES,  salsas.
author: Dorothy N.

description:
I started coming here when I lived around the corner.  There is one woman who has worked here ever since I've been going religiously who is always very nice about my broken Spanish.  The rest of the staff are nice but tend to act busy and stressed out when it seems to be slow...

Gets busy around dinner time (6-8) so expect a line out the door (although the counter is literally inches from the door, so you still won't wait long).  I suggest the fajita chicken super burrito, but no lettuce for me.

Oh and... despite rave reviews of El Castillito up the street, I can't stand that place.
author: Cole I.

description:
A friend and I weren't sure where to eat. Like a prophet sent from God, a crackhead steps up to us and says, "Don't eat at Castillito, eat here. Castillito doesn't wash their hands, and this place has fresh vegetables! Look, they're cutting some right now!"

I love Castillito, but I wanted to try something new, so my friend and I went in. Got their wet Azteca burrito and it was the best wet burrito I'd had in a long time. It's surprisingly spicy and the meat has a good flavor. Their red salsa from the salsa bar is also really good, it almost tastes slightly italian pizza sauce-ish. The big problem is that their food is somewhat inconsistent. Some days it's great, some days it's not all that good.

This place is a good alternative for when Castillito is closed or you just want to switch it up.
author: Daniel R.

description: The tostadas, are good. I just started eating here cause my girl. One time the tostada wasnt as good.....so you have to pick your days......need to check da burridahs.........hmmmmm........chicken!!!!
author: freaky r.

description:
alright, so this is a review update. i have tried new menu items and have not found any more rocks in my beans. 

my personal favorite is a spicy chicken taco with black beans and pico.
the chicken is flavorful and tender, the beans are iight. 
my first two experiences here were awful but any time i have been there lately, the food has been pretty good.
author: Carly W.

description:
Wow.... $3.25 for a "Super Taco" gets you basically a small taco tortilla with meat, cheese, sour cream, salsa, and guacamole piled on to high heaven. Best deal ever. I couldn't even reach the taco at the bottom of the plate. Good thing they give you free chips to dig your way through.

btw, props to them for getting 100 on their health inspection. :)
author: Richie K.

description:
BOO! after seeing that this place had such high marks, especially with such an equally well rated neighbor up the street (castillito) i thought i'd give it a try for lunch. what did i order?

regular chicken burrito w/ cheese (on the menu)
chips
horchata

how was it? bland, tasteless, the cheese came in one big clump and the horchata was MEH. i would never go back to this place with such a better alternative 4 doors away.
author: Greg A.

description:
I stumbled upon this place since the Muni J just stops right in front of it. The first time I got the chile relleno dinner, and the second time I got a super veggie burrito. Both times I was very happy -- both with the food and with the value for the price (~$4).

Particularly because of the location, and because they're so consistently good, this place has become my neighborhood tacqueria. The food is good and cheap and fast, and there's a little salsa bar and free chips. What else do you need?
author: John C.

description: Yes! This place is so good and their rice, beans, and chips are vegetarian! It's very reasonably priced- a super veggie burrito for $5.70 and everyone that works there is very sweet and helpful. The food is delicious and they have a decent salsa bar.
author: Sara D.

description: had a burrito here and it wasnt too good. quesadilla was good though
author: Mohammad A.

description: As I type this, I am experiencing uncontrollable volcanic flatulent eruptions. Came in last night with my friend who had spotted it the previous day and, ignoring my Yelp tendencies and generally skeptical consumerist tendencies, I ordered both the most expensive and crappiest Mexican food in my life. Ordered a shrimp taco, got a flavorless fish taco, for which the salmon had the texture of soggy bread. Ordered a chile relleno burrito, experienced an overwhelmingly large burrito that was 2/3 peas and rice with a tiny chile relleno stuffed in. I felt ripped off and sickly following this memorably sickening taqueria experience, and to top it off the people working were unexpectedly rushed with the minimal traffic.
author: Peter H.

description:
They're cheap.
They're fast.
They're open pretty late.
The food isn't too bad.
The place is pretty clean.

Heck, if that was a woman I'd date her - but it's not, so instead I go there and order take-out maybe once a week.

"Two shrimp tacos and one Pastor taco with spicy salsa. To go please! Thanks!". Eight dollars and change later I'm out of there.
author: Rich S.

description: Great vegetarian options including tofu, cactus, or grilled veggies.  Always tempting me on my walk home from the gym...
author: Kacie O.

description:
We had a super crappy meal here the other day. I don't know if it was just an off night for them or 8 million degrees inside and the staff was overworked but whatever, it just sucked.
We usually go to castillito (just a few doors down and a million times better) but we were feeling lazy about not having cash and casa mexicana takes cards.
My husband had a steak plate which was basically an open faced burrito and he said it tasted like dog food and I had a prawn burrito. It took so long for them to make (seriously it felt like an hour but it was really crowded and hot inside) and they didn't give us those little cups for the salsa until we asked repeatedly for them.
I've actually eaten here before and it wasn't that bad but next time I think I'll just go to Castillo where I know it will be delicious.
author: Emily L.

description:
Enchiladas = QUE BUENO!

Give this place a try, and you will kiss La Taqueria (= OVERRATED) goodbye!

I have been dining out in SF for nearly 3 weeks straight, and this place finally inspired me to write my first Yelp review.  This place is light years ahead of your typical hole-in-the-wall Mexican joint.  They use high quality ingredients, no lard, and even have tofu simmered in ranchero sauce for those who don't eat meat.

Me?  I eat meat, and meat I ate.  They have FIVE different kinds of chicken, two of which I sampled in my enchiladas.  Both were very tasty and distinctive, and the large, lean, succulent chunks of all-white breast meat are oh-so-good.  And this is coming from someone who almost NEVER orders chicken.

So I have been on a quest for the perfect enchilada for several years now, and this place is the best I've found so far.  The red sauce has a complex and distinctive taste--much better than your usual tomato drivel.

Chips, refried beans, rice, and salsa bar all are well above par too.  Mix in a friendly kitchen staff that seems to have deep roots in the neighborhood, and you simply can't go wrong.
author: John D.

description:
Delicious, and one of the only affordable places in Noe Valley.  Service is quick, food is fresh, and the atmosphere is fun and casual.

It's everything I want in a local Mexican restaurant.
author: Alex C.

description:
Good food. If you work in the area- great place for a quick bite that's extremely filling and cheap.

Yum.
author: Art A.

description: Sour cream was like white water.  The guacamole was 90% cucumber...no joke. Just charge people more and give them real guacamole.  Cucumber is unacceptable.
author: Vincent C.

description: The Best Mexican Food in the City! A payday favorite!
author: Sara G.

description: Casa Mexicana I burritos are alright, but nothing special here.  I'd rather go to Mission/24th Sts for a burrito at El Farolito.
author: George L.

description: Had a tofu ranchero burrito; pretty decent. This branch has one of the better interiors (pleasant looking, at least) as far as Mexican fast food joints go.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I like this place alot better than the one next to this place! 

Decent veggie brito, awesome chips! Also love cheese enchilada plate they have!

Also love Frida's photos and Diego's paintings inside!
author: moshi m.

description:
I love this place. Fast, friendly service and damn good food. 
Best place to grab a bite walking home from the Church station.

And it's dirt cheap - well, at least for this city.
author: Pam Z.

description:
Casa Mexicana is pretty ok.
I like their burritos but nothing to write home about.
I prefer Azteca just south on Church.
author: Joshua E.

description:
For someone who's been to more than a few mexican restaurants this place is one that I always keep coming back to again and again.

The burritos are made how I want them and are a good size. The nachos are also really good (even though nachos are a made up dish). I guess because I speak Spanish the people there can understand better what I want and what I don't want. 

Their sister restaurant in Noe Valley has equally good food where if I was in that neighborhood more I would go there just as often.

Thanks Casa Mexicana for the good burritos and nachos...oh yeah and for serving those Coronas I like as well!
author: Alexandra A.

description:
This is one of our default local restaurants when we feel like Mexican food. The quality of the food is sometimes inconsistent, and depending on who builds your burrito, it can be quite variable too. 

I prefer this place over some other taquerias because they have more authentic choices unlike those who have only Gringo items on the menu. The Chicken Mole is very tasty, as is the Chorizo, and Pork in Green Tomatillo Sauce.

Overall I would say this place is "quite good" for a cheap and casual meal. It is sometimes dissapointing due to inconsistency, but for the price, it is not too much of a gamble.
author: Adrian L.

description: Had for dinner tonight...not good, the food was stale, my quesadilla had hard pieces of meat in it....I honestly will not go here again.....ick.
author: Brian S.

description:
If you are stuck in the area and craving a burrito, do not fear this place... Good selection and you will not be disappointed because they do make good grub. 

However if you are looking for a burrito to tell your friends about... keep looking. SF is blessed with more than a few places that make Casa Taqueria just about equivalent to making a burrito at your own Casa.
author: Joseph M.

description: Sorry, but you have to try harder Casa Mexicana. You have prime real-esate yet you've rested on your laurels instead of producing great food like your competitors (La Taqueria, Los Coyotes, Cancun). If you do a good job, geography helps you capture the Castro and Lower Haight market.
author: Andrew H.

description: I'm a general lover of tacos, but I really did NOT like what I got. The carne asada taco was way too watery, too big for me to actually pick up and eat, and just an overall weird tasting taco. I swear, maybe in another life it was probably a burrito or taco salad. I didn't like the price I paid, either. This is what I get for not walking a couple of feet up to El Castillito. It's doubtful that I will ever go back here.
author: Caroline L.

description: I found Casa Mexicana highly disappointing. I only rarely treat myself to burritos lately (trying to lose weight), so it's a bummer when I order a burrito and it comes with overcooked chicken and some serious temperature issues. I'm going to stick with Zapata or La Fajita from now on.
author: Curtis F.

description: I hate to be a downer.  I really didn't like this place.  I got a veggie quesadilla, which was so-so.  My friends got the cactus tacos, which were wayy too salty, and the salmon tacos were apparently not good either, although I didn't try them myself.  I did try the cactus and it tasted like salt.  Add to that the fact that the dining room was cold.  Not my favorite place in the city so far.
author: jen h.

description: The tofu ranchero burrito is there for you, like a good friend, when you get yourself into hungry trouble. And it's here at Church & Market, the center of the world.  Get it with avocado slices, not guacamole.
author: Megan W.

description: A favorite hole-in-the-wall eatery, I usually get the Nachos con pollo which is a five hour, stomach-filling meal! Really, I don't need to eat much more after this. I had their tacos con pollo today with extra jalepenos and a wonderful hot salsa. I like the smokey flavor of the roasted chicken though most of the times I ask for the 'pollo rojo' which is a piquant red sauce. Try the burrito nopales for something different..the cactus picks up the other flavors incorporated! The staff is friendly and I try practicing my Spanish while ordering. Prices are VERY reasonable too!
author: michael s.

description: You'd have to be insane, retarded or tongueless to go here when Castillito is 20 steps to your right.
author: merkley m.

description:
As I walked in door of Casa Mexicana I thought "Why haven't I been here before?" Clean, friendly, and with cool mosaic portaits of Frida Khalo it was a refreshing alternative to the interior of El Castillito down the street. 
Heard rumors of great chile rellenos burrito here but my appetite was only ready for a taco. A veggie taco. Lucky too cuz Casa Mexicana is kind of expensive. Taco, chips, and agua in hand I headed to the salsa bar; green was good. Smashed the whole plate in my face. Straightforward and tasty, for a taco. Girlfriend had the grilled chicken version with onions and peppers and felt the same way. Moderate Mexicana.
author: Corey D.

description:
all that beer at lucky 13 can't be good for me, especially on an empty stomach. oh, and did i tell you i'm asian? um, light weight? guilty! so before i make a complete ass of myself and get thrown out of lucky 13, i usually walk over to casa mexicana and get me some cheap mexican food to soak up the alcohol. casa mexicana offers solid food that's easy on the wallet. so you should have plenty of money to go back to lucky 13 for more beer afterward. in my opinion, the food is more traditional than papalote or pancho villa, but you better ask maria d if you want the resident mexican food expert's opinion. i swear, that girl should have her own mexican food blog.

in conclusion, casa mexicana may not be a destination spot, but its close proximity to lucky 13 (a destination spot indeed) is a blessing............and thanks to casa mexicana, i have never been thrown out of lucky 13. now how many people can say that?
author: frisco j.

description: Casa Mexicana's a clean establishment--a good mexican food joint in the Castro.  The place looks small from the outside, but there's more seating towards the rear.  The menu features a separate veggie menu with options that include a tofu ranchero burrito.  Portions are hearty and worth it.  And it's always a plus when they take plastic.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
i still have yet to find "mi casa" for burritos in my neighborhood. a word for the wise -- if you are getting your burrito 'for here' and want it wrapped in foil, make sure to ask them for it!

first of all, i came here absolutely starving and I still wasn't completely satisfied... usually when you're hungry, most things taste amazing. in fact, that's my whole theory about why certain people are obsessed with specific sushi hot spots: when you wait forever for your food and are starving and salivating, almost anything tastes fantastic.... but i digress... that is neither here nor there!

3 stars because the restaurant was clean, the staff was friendly, and the food was fresh. delicious tomatillo salsa as well!

2 stars deducted because my super veggie burrito was COLD :( also, i hated the way it didn't come wrapped in foil (since i didn't get it 'to go' because then not only is it difficult to eat, but it loses temperature quickly. the filling tasted good but not great.... left me kind of feeling 'eh.' also, the chips were somewhat overcooked -- almost dark!

would like to give it another try at some point and make sure to ask for my burrito wrapped in foil!!!!
author: Jill M.

description: make sure that your stomach has room for their huge, nummy platters.  the shrimp taco shocked me with its size (seriously huge) and price (truly affordable).  i've uploaded a pic of my taco,  don't be jealous.  ^_^
author: Anita J.

description: Lord knows I appreciate a tofu burrito, but not one that tastes like tomato soup.
author: Tovah S.

description: Always good food, lots of seating, and open late.
author: Aneuwave V.

description:
this place is grim. i've eaten here twice. the first time i thought it was the worst mexican food i've ever had in my life. a few years later, in a pinch, i went back...hoping that they had gotten better and that the last time was a fluke. no such luck....easily the worst mexican food i've ever had again. i couldn't even finish my meal....and i was starving. 

you should try this place out. the lack of flavor is amazing. its worth it almost to see how bad it is. it'd be like smelling something that stinks even though you know it stinks just so you can have a shared 'Eeeeewwwww' experience with your friends. 

blech!
author: h h.

description: Delicious burritos, a green salsa to die for  (seriously, we smuggle little cups of it home with us), and where else can you get super nachos with chicken mole on top? They really serve huge portions, but it's so yummy I trade the discomfort of stuffing my belly with the joy of eating those last few bites. Too bad the dining area is a bit dark and unlovely.
author: Phoebe J.

description: I give them a one star and that's being generous. Their customer service is horrible and their food is NOT great.
author: Omar J.

description: An OK spot. nothing outstanding, but not bad. hard to choose it over el castillo just up the street, though.
author: Tom H.

description: Anyone that knows me knows that I could eat 3 burritos a day and be happy. This place not only makes wonderful burritos and salsa....but they are also super friendly. I seriously want to hug each person that works there every time I go in (at least twice a week).
author: Camille L.

description: Where else can you get a burrito with lovely, flavorful tofu, and crisp, delicious vegetables, while your friend devours his version of 'tasty'... which comes in the form of meaty something. Very yummy burritos. Customizable in a cafeteria style. Clean, hospitable atmosphere for consumption of said burrito. And I've never finished it in one siting. That's eatin.
author: Ania W.

description: I go at least once a week. Best options: Super Burrito (Steak) or Super Nachos (Steak)
author: John B.

description: I love this place.  They're open late, very convenient.  Best part of all, is brown rice.  I hate white rice, and while there are other places that have brown, usually those places assume you want no flavor on it.  I used to go to El Castillo, but they are very cheap with the cheese, and I eat veggie burritos, they've got to have cheese.  Nice people, great salsa bar, they don't wrap my burrito in 3 pieces of foil that will be thrown away 10 minutes later.
author: julie t.

description: As a soon to be resident in the Duboce Park/Castro neighborhood, I was thrilled to happen upon this place on Saturday afternoon. Whole wheat tortillas, black beans, spicy salsa, and good guacamole. And burritos run less than $5. And they're pretty big. I gave myself a food coma. You can't beat that. AND it's within walking distance of my new digs. They've got a small dining area towards the back of the place. But judging by the traffic on Saturday, this is more of a take-it-on-the-road kind of place. Cheap Price + Good Food = Happy Marie
author: Marie M.

description: I had a fun Christmas Eve dinner with my friends here. I ordered the green chicken mole, which was pretty good. They have refillable tortilla chips with a salsa bar. It's all self-serve, but I didn't mind. I thought the setting was very "luxurious" without being luxurious at all. Oh, the price was good too.
author: Alex Y.

description: I heard great things about this place and wanted to check it out. I ordered a burrito and was disappointed. The sauce they used was not that great and the guacamole wasn't very fresh. The chips were a little stale but at least the salsa was good. We sat at a table with the window seal covered in cushions which were quite dirty. I wasn't impressed
author: Denise S.

description: These guys have been life savers for me on a number of occasions.  Their food is fresh - a HUGE bonus when you are talking Mexican.  Ther aguas frescas and horchatas are always mighty tasty.  Oooh, and those chips...
author: Shane L.

description: I thought I was being adventurous and coming here instead of Azteca but they're exactly the same!  Fortunately, it was just what I wanted b/c I was peeved at Azteca but missed the food...so I suppose going to Casa Mexicana across Market will be the way to get my burrito.  They're slow here also and also have a credit card surcharge though...but it's convenient, good, and clean.
author: Debbie Y.

description: TACOS. This is the best place for tacos in the city. They are heaping--much more filling than your average taco and they have multiple delicious vegetarian options.
author: Hillary L.

description: The owner is hot, the staff are friendly (and remember your face), and the food tastes fresh.  I really like this place.  They could improve upon their salsa selections.
author: Adrian N.

description: Wha? The fact that this place has four stars on Yelp boggles and confuzzles my poor little brain. Hungover as FUCK on Sunday morning, I wandered down the street to this place to get a veggie burrito in hopes that some rice and beans would soak up the nasty funkedupness in my stomach. Instead, I got the most mediocre burrito I've ever chewed up, digested, and excreted. It wasn't bad, just abolutely nothing special. So much so that I can't believe I'm even writing this review.
author: Alyssa R.

description: Great little mexican spot for what it is. The carne asada in the good size burrito I got here really hit the spot. The salsas were some of the best I've had in SF and the chips were solid as well. Great for a fast and cheap bite of quality authentic mexican food. Thumbs up.
author: M L.

description: I saw go the  extra few blocks to get your burrito at Papalote down  the  street! This  place  isn't horrible, but to me  the cardinal  sin of Mexican  food is the chewy, greasy, fatty, chicken. Guess  what  kind  of chicken  was in my burrito at Casa? The  one  redeeming  factor was  the quac is pretty good and  I love a salsa bar, but couldn't  get  over  the  chicken.
author: Tara T.

description: Way cleaner and better, but flavor-wise there is something definitely lacking from the food. They are really nice though and they do have decent quesadillas. Tacos are sort of blah though. The meat has no flavor, it's true.
author: Gina R.

description: Solid.  I like the steak super burrito in a wheat tortilla with black beans and mild salsa the best.  They charge $0.25 extra if you use a credit card.
author: Marcus C.

description: Pretty delicious and great for being so close to my house. My food was pretty good but the salsa was a little bit too spicy for me. This place is great considering this is the first mexican place i've gone to in SF that didn't start in San Mateo.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Check out the hand crafted tile tables in the back room - a nice place for a late breakfast.
author: David H.

description:
Congratulations Casa Mexicana on having the WORST super burrito I've had in San Francisco - and I've had a lot!
I stopped in here because I was taking the J home and it was on the way. I order:
"A carne asada super burrito - no rice - refried beans - to go." Simple, right?
The person starts my order: "what kind of meat?" "um . . .carne asada" "regular or super?" "um . . .super" Until she started asking questions, I was confused if she was even working on my order, given the two tablespoons of meat on the grill.  "what kind of beans?" "um . . . refried beans" . . . She proceeds to fill up the tortilla with a HUGE amount of beans - we're talking like 3 cups of beans here. Then she starts to pile on the rice "oh - no rice" I say. Then, she plops it down on a plate "it's to g . .." Aw, hell - I'll just have it here.
They use guacamole instead of avocados - a burrito pet peeve of mine, but what can you do? Their salsas were disgusting: they tasted old and fermented and like plastic - as if they made up a big batch on Monday and just kept it around all week. Come to think of it, that's probably what they do. 
The meat was just gross - it tasted like dog, or what I imagine dog to taste like. REALLY tough, stringy, and flavorless. And the salt! I don't mind some salt, but the beans were SO salty it just took over the taste of everything else. Then to add insult to injury, the thing was not even folded tight, so it fell apart when I tried to eat it. 
If I hadn't have been so hungry, I wouldn't have even tried to eat this garbage. I guess this place banks on the fact they're the only taqueria in the neighborhood. It wouldn't stay in business in another neighborhood.
author: David C.

description: They changed management or something about 9 months ago. Much of the usual friendly staff gone; prices increased; manager at the register who seems to care much less about service than anyone else there. I use to go weekly - for years, now just once in a while. Their food is still good - oh yes - but you pay the price - in cost and in service.
author: mike g.

description: My advice, take that little walk toward the Mission.   Dude, canned shrimp?  cheap yes.  good no.  fresh. not even close. passable drunk/stoned food, sure, but so is taco bell.   Was hoping for more from a local place but it's the 7-eleven of taco joints - cheap and convenient.  oh well, plenty of other choices.
author: top b.

description: I agree, it's a lot more appealing and appetizing than the place down the street.  The prices are right in line with what you would find outside of the Mission district.  The carnitas is delicious and always moist.  The only hangup I have about this place is sometimes the burritos can be cold.  At first, I thought it had to do with them putting lettuce in the burrito, and the lettuce cooling everything off.  But, then I ordered a burrito without lettuce and still had the same chilly result.  As a point of interest, I have gone two more times since then, and have not encountered a cold burrito.  The ingredients are consistently, fresh; the salsa bar (albeit) a small one is a great plus too!
author: DamnGringo X.

description: Casa Mexicana is another place around the upper market area that's just fine.  Their food is fresh, not too greasy, cheap and pleasant to eat.  We never find that anything stands out in particular, however.  The salsas range from decent to so-so, and the guacamole is a bit sub-par, but certainly never bad.  The place is decorated really nicely, and interestingly, with Frida embedded in tiles (which is always awesome), and is one of the more pleasant taquerias for dining in.
author: Nicole and Kayvon B.

description:
I used to like this place (especially when its sister taqueria Taqueria Azteca was too crowded) ... until I found out about their alleged abusive practices against their employees: 

http://cbs5.com/business/azteca.taqueria.complaints.2.779706.html

Now I wouldn't touch this place with a 10-foot pole.
author: Randy D.

description: One word......AMAZING!  Delicious taqueria sort of place! Staff is very friendly. TONS of items on the menu. Very fresh and clean. The green salsa is some of the best green salsa I have ever had in my life.....and the best thing of all, is that they have a salsa bar so you can help yourself to as much as you would like.  The food was excellent. I'll definately be back!
author: Julie G.

description: i won't get caught up in the "best burrito" wars SF has become famous for, but this place is pretty damn good. it's clean, well-lit, they use fresh, tasty ingredients and (unlike many burrito joints) the staff is actually friendly here. there's another tacqueria on this stretch of church, but you should avoid that one like the plague you'd probably contract if you stepped inside - stick with casa mexicana (the one closest to market) and you'll avoid that nasty doctor's visit.
author: RT G.

description: my tippity toppity most favorite mexican food joint in the city. super friendly, super yummy, i usually get food to go but when i stay, there is almost always a place to sit. im always super satisfied. super as in coma.  the good kind of  coma.
author: coffeecake j.

description: I want to start by saying that I am from Colorado where we smother everything, and we make a mean chile relleno burrito. I have been homesick for years for that kind of massive gratification. What stands out in my mind about this place and their fare is the variety on the menu and the smoky flavorful salsa' and enchilada sauce. I personally sampled an azteca burrito with Chile relleno and it was so flavorful hot delicious that I have no problem saying it is my favorite in the city. The chips are fresh, and the selection includes tofu in several different styles. The red salsa is so addictive and flavorful/ reasonable spicy that it would be wise to get 2 cups.  The warm atmosphere is inviting and the dining area is spacious and separate from the street which is nice if you want to have an actual conversation. It is very colorful with Freida Kahlo reproductions on the wall. The stress here is that yes it is quick cheap  but instead of being a taqueria it is much like the name suggests a house of Mexican flavor and culture.
author: crystal j.

description: The back room gets a bit smoky at times, but the food here is amazing and fast+fresh
author: Nick M.

description: I was born and raised in El Paso, Texas.  For those of you who don't know where that is, it is a border town in West Texas.  I am 100% Hispanic, and as you can imagine I know a thing or two about Mexican food.  I love Casa Mexicana, or as I call it Mi Casa (don't ask).  I will say their food differs slightly than the homemade Mexican food I am use to.  But that doesn't matter.  When I say differ, here is what I mean.  Where I come from, we don't offer spinach tortillas or black beans. But I don't mind because they are delicious. Their burritos are beyond huge, and mighty tasty at that. They have great quesadillas, and cold beer (which is very important to Mexicans). The staff is always so friendly, and to no surprise at all, VERY speedy at what they do!  If you are in the neighborhood, try it out...I think you will like it.  BTW...I am not saying this is the best in the city.  Believe me I have had some great Mexican food in the Mission, it's just so hard to decide which place best represents my fathers cooking.
author: Samantha R.

description: I LOVE BURRITOS.  I'm from SoCal and I grew up in a Mexican neighborhood.  This is the first five-star rating I given but it deserves it.  Okay...it seems, a lot of people think that in order for Mexican food to be "authentic" it has to be unhealthy.  WRONG.  They have good rice if you like rice in your burritos.  I love the pinto beans.  They use quality cheese not dehydrated nastiness.  They have good salsa.  You have a selection of tortillas: flour, whole wheat, tomato, and spinach.  I hadn't ever had a spinach tortilla before I came here and strangly I liked it.  I'm vegetarian but I haven't always been and I know what good meat looks like when I see and smell it.  They're plain chicken looks really good.  You can also get real Mexican Coke's in the bottle made with real sugar and not government subsidized corn syrup.  The ladies and gentleman behind the counter are GREAT say hi, introduce yourself, they'll remember you!  While you're there check out all the Frida and Diego picture-tiles.
author: Amanda A.

description: I usually go to El Castillo when I'm done in these parts, but I thought I'd check this place out last night -- mainly because there was less of a line. I guess there's a reason the line is shorter. The burritos are just ok. They're a bit smaller than what you usually get in the bay area. The chicken was tasty but it was lukewarm. Overall, it was not memorable. If I come here again, I want to try the fajita burrito because it gets cooked to order.
author: Luke F.

description: This place is the closest taqueria to my place (mi casa if you will)...so when I crave some comida mexicana I head to Mi Casa Mexicana.  I would say it is definitely in the top tier of taquerias in the city.  The interior is a bit nicer than most other taquerias...with Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera memorabilia around the place.  I haven't lived here long but I have done my fair share of eating tacos, burritos, and the like.  It's quality is on par with Toro, Pancho Villa, and Taqueria (I haven't been to the fabled Papalote yet).  They have a fairly wide selection of meats - it seems like they have a few more choices than some other places.  As long as I stay true to my staples of Super Tacos and quesadillas (with sour cream and guac) - I always leave happy.  I ordered a chili relleno on my last visit - and I don't think I'll order that sloppy, soggy mess of cheese again.  Their salsa bar is not QUITE as good as some of the competition, but they do have cilantro, diced onions, and jalapeos on the bar.  They also serve "Mexican" Coke...which I am assuming has a different flavor than normal US of A Coke.  Definitely better than the competing taqueria right up the street.
author: Adam M.

description: Great mexican food!  Much better than Castillito, which I found to be greasy and heavy..  This place is lighter, the ingredients are fresh and the prices are great.  This place is definitely in the regular rotation.
author: Kristen T.

description: i'm a sucker for salsa bars...and they have a great one. i love their salsa verde. also, they serve breakfast burritos all day...so when you wake up from a long night of drinking and it's 2pm, get your breakfast on here.
author: selma s.
